an6.55:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate.
an6.55:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.

an6.55:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā soṇo rājagahe viharati sītavanasmiṃ.
an6.55:1.3.eng: Now at that time Venerable Soṇa was staying near Rājagaha in the Cool Grove.

an6.55:1.4.pli: Atha kho āyasmato soṇassa rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
an6.55:1.4.eng: Then as he was in private retreat this thought came to his mind,

an6.55:1.5.pli: “ye kho keci bhagavato sāvakā āraddhavīriyā viharanti, ahaṃ tesaṃ aññataro.
an6.55:1.5.eng: “I am one of the Buddha’s most energetic disciples.

an6.55:1.6.pli: Atha ca pana me na anupādāya āsavehi cittaṃ vimuccati, saṃvijjanti kho pana me kule bhogā, sakkā bhogā ca bhuñjituṃ puññāni ca kātuṃ.
an6.55:1.6.eng: Yet my mind is not freed from defilements by not grasping. But my family has wealth. I could enjoy that wealth and make merit.

an6.55:1.7.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattitvā bhoge ca bhuñjeyyaṃ puññāni ca kareyyan”ti.
an6.55:1.7.eng: Why don’t I resign the training and return to a lesser life, so I can enjoy my wealth and make merit?”

an6.55:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmato soṇassa cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evamevaṃ kho—gijjhakūṭe pabbate antarahito sītavane āyasmato soṇassa sammukhe pāturahosi.
an6.55:2.1.eng: Then the Buddha knew what Venerable Soṇa was thinking. As easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, he vanished from the Vulture’s Peak and reappeared in the Cool Grove in front of Soṇa,

an6.55:2.2.eng: and sat on the seat spread out.

an6.55:2.3.pli: Āyasmāpi kho soṇo bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
an6.55:2.3.eng: Soṇa bowed to the Buddha and sat down to one side.

an6.55:2.4.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ soṇaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:

an6.55:3.1.pli: “Nanu te, soṇa, rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
an6.55:3.1.eng: “Soṇa, as you were in private retreat didn’t this thought come to your mind:

an6.55:3.2.pli: ‘ye kho keci bhagavato sāvakā āraddhavīriyā viharanti, ahaṃ tesaṃ aññataro.
an6.55:3.2.eng: ‘I am one of the Buddha’s most energetic disciples.

an6.55:3.3.pli: Atha ca pana me na anupādāya āsavehi cittaṃ vimuccati, saṃvijjanti kho pana me kule bhogā, sakkā bhogā ca bhuñjituṃ puññāni ca kātuṃ.
an6.55:3.3.eng: Yet my mind is not freed from defilements by not grasping. But my family has wealth. I could enjoy that wealth and make merit.

an6.55:3.4.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattitvā bhoge ca bhuñjeyyaṃ puññāni ca kareyyan’”ti?
an6.55:3.4.eng: Why don’t I resign the training and return to a lesser life, so I can enjoy my wealth and make merit?’”

an6.55:4.2.pli: kusalo tvaṃ pubbe agāriyabhūto vīṇāya tantissare”ti?
an6.55:4.2.eng: When you were still a layman, weren’t you a good player of the arched harp?”

an6.55:4.4.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, soṇa, yadā te vīṇāya tantiyo accāyatā honti, api nu te vīṇā tasmiṃ samaye saravatī vā hoti kammaññā vā”ti?
an6.55:4.4.eng: “When your harp’s strings were tuned too tight, was it resonant and playable?”

an6.55:5.1.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, soṇa, yadā te vīṇāya tantiyo atisithilā honti, api nu te vīṇā tasmiṃ samaye saravatī vā hoti kammaññā vā”ti?
an6.55:5.1.eng: “When your harp’s strings were tuned too slack, was it resonant and playable?”

an6.55:6.1.pli: “Yadā pana te, soṇa, vīṇāya tantiyo na accāyatā honti nātisithilā same guṇe patiṭṭhitā, api nu te vīṇā tasmiṃ samaye saravatī vā hoti kammaññā vā”ti?
an6.55:6.1.eng: “But when your harp’s strings were tuned neither too tight nor too slack, but fixed at an even tension, was it resonant and playable?”

an6.55:7.1.pli: “Evamevaṃ kho, soṇa, accāraddhavīriyaṃ uddhaccāya saṃvattati, atisithilavīriyaṃ kosajjāya saṃvattati.
an6.55:7.1.eng: “In the same way, Soṇa, when energy is too forceful it leads to restlessness. When energy is too slack it leads to laziness.

an6.55:7.2.pli: Tasmātiha tvaṃ, soṇa, vīriyasamathaṃ adhiṭṭhaha, indriyānañca samataṃ paṭivijjha, tattha ca nimittaṃ gaṇhāhī”ti.
an6.55:7.2.eng: So, Soṇa, you should focus on energy and serenity, find a balance of the faculties, and learn the character of this situation.”

an6.55:7.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā soṇo bhagavato paccassosi.

an6.55:7.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ soṇaṃ iminā ovādena ovaditvā—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evamevaṃ kho—sītavane antarahito gijjhakūṭe pabbate pāturahosi.
an6.55:7.4.eng: After advising Soṇa like this, the Buddha, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, vanished from the Cool Grove and reappeared on the Vulture’s Peak.

an6.55:8.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā soṇo aparena samayena vīriyasamathaṃ adhiṭṭhāsi, indriyānañca samataṃ paṭivijjhi, tattha ca nimittaṃ aggahesi.
an6.55:8.1.eng: After some time Soṇa focused on energy and serenity, found a balance of the faculties, and learned the pattern of this situation.

an6.55:8.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā soṇo eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anāgāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi.
an6.55:8.2.eng: Then Soṇa, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme culmination of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

an6.55:8.3.pli: “Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā”ti abbhaññāsi.
an6.55:8.3.eng: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”

an6.55:8.4.pli: Aññataro ca panāyasmā soṇo arahataṃ ahosi.
an6.55:8.4.eng: And Venerable Soṇa became one of the perfected.

an6.55:9.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmato soṇassa arahattappattassa etadahosi:
an6.55:9.1.eng: Then, when Soṇa had attained perfection, he thought,

an6.55:9.2.pli: “yannūnāhaṃ yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkameyyaṃ; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavato santike aññaṃ byākareyyan”ti.
an6.55:9.2.eng: “Why don’t I go to the Buddha and declare my enlightenment in his presence?”

an6.55:9.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmā soṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā soṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an6.55:9.3.eng: Then Soṇa went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an6.55:10.1.pli: “Yo so, bhante, bhikkhu arahaṃ khīṇāsavo vusitavā katakaraṇīyo ohitabhāro anuppattasadattho parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojano sammadaññāvimutto, so cha ṭhānāni adhimutto hoti—
an6.55:10.1.eng: “Sir, a mendicant who is perfected—with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and is rightly freed through enlightenment—is dedicated to six things.

an6.55:10.2.pli: nekkhammādhimutto hoti, pavivekādhimutto hoti, abyāpajjādhimutto hoti, taṇhākkhayādhimutto hoti, upādānakkhayādhimutto hoti, asammohādhimutto hoti.
an6.55:10.2.eng: They are dedicated to renunciation, seclusion, kindness, the ending of craving, the ending of grasping, and mental clarity.

an6.55:11.1.pli: Siyā kho pana, bhante, idhekaccassa āyasmato evamassa:
an6.55:11.1.eng: It may be, sir, that one of the venerables here thinks:

an6.55:11.2.eng: ‘Maybe this venerable is dedicated to renunciation solely out of mere faith.’

an6.55:11.3.pli: Na kho panetaṃ, bhante, evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
an6.55:11.3.eng: But it should not be seen like this.

an6.55:11.4.pli: Khīṇāsavo, bhante, bhikkhu vusitavā katakaraṇīyo karaṇīyaṃ attano asamanupassanto katassa vā paṭicayaṃ khayā rāgassa vītarāgattā nekkhammādhimutto hoti, khayā dosassa vītadosattā nekkhammādhimutto hoti, khayā mohassa vītamohattā nekkhammādhimutto hoti.
an6.55:11.4.eng: A mendicant with defilements ended does not see in themselves anything more to do, or anything that needs improvement. They’re dedicated to renunciation because they’re free of greed, hate, and delusion with the end of greed, hate, and delusion.

an6.55:12.1.pli: Siyā kho pana, bhante, idhekaccassa āyasmato evamassa:
an6.55:12.1.eng: It may be, sir, that one of the venerables here thinks:

an6.55:12.2.eng: ‘Maybe this venerable is dedicated to seclusion because they enjoy possessions, honor, and popularity.’

an6.55:12.3.pli: Na kho panetaṃ, bhante, evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
an6.55:12.3.eng: But it should not be seen like this. …

an6.55:12.4.pli: Khīṇāsavo, bhante, bhikkhu vusitavā katakaraṇīyo karaṇīyaṃ attano asamanupassanto katassa vā paṭicayaṃ khayā rāgassa vītarāgattā pavivekādhimutto hoti, khayā dosassa vītadosattā pavivekādhimutto hoti, khayā mohassa vītamohattā pavivekādhimutto hoti.

an6.55:13.1.pli: Siyā kho pana, bhante, idhekaccassa āyasmato evamassa:
an6.55:13.1.eng: It may be, sir, that one of the venerables here thinks:

an6.55:13.2.eng: ‘Maybe this venerable is dedicated to kindness because they believe that adhering to precepts and observances is essential.’

an6.55:13.3.pli: Na kho panetaṃ, bhante, evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
an6.55:13.3.eng: But it should not be seen like this. …

an6.55:13.4.pli: Khīṇāsavo, bhante, bhikkhu vusitavā katakaraṇīyo karaṇīyaṃ attano asamanupassanto katassa vā paṭicayaṃ khayā rāgassa vītarāgattā abyāpajjādhimutto hoti, khayā dosassa vītadosattā abyāpajjādhimutto hoti, khayā mohassa vītamohattā abyāpajjādhimutto hoti.

an6.55:14.1.pli: Khayā rāgassa vītarāgattā taṇhākkhayādhimutto hoti, khayā dosassa vītadosattā taṇhākkhayādhimutto hoti, khayā mohassa vītamohattā taṇhākkhayādhimutto hoti.
an6.55:14.1.eng: They’re dedicated to the ending of craving because they’re free of greed, hate, and delusion with the end of greed, hate, and delusion.

an6.55:15.1.pli: Khayā rāgassa vītarāgattā upādānakkhayādhimutto hoti, khayā dosassa vītadosattā upādānakkhayādhimutto hoti, khayā mohassa vītamohattā upādānakkhayādhimutto hoti.
an6.55:15.1.eng: They’re dedicated to the ending of grasping because they’re free of greed, hate, and delusion with the end of greed, hate, and delusion.

an6.55:16.1.pli: Khayā rāgassa vītarāgattā asammohādhimutto hoti, khayā dosassa vītadosattā asammohādhimutto hoti, khayā mohassa vītamohattā asammohādhimutto hoti.
an6.55:16.1.eng: They’re dedicated to clarity of mind because they’re free of greed, hate, and delusion with the end of greed, hate, and delusion.

an6.55:17.1.pli: Evaṃ sammā vimuttacittassa, bhante, bhikkhuno bhusā cepi cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā cakkhussa āpāthaṃ āgacchanti, nevassa cittaṃ pariyādiyanti.
an6.55:17.1.eng: When a mendicant’s mind is rightly freed like this, even if compelling sights come into the range of vision they don’t overcome their mind.

an6.55:17.2.pli: Amissīkatamevassa cittaṃ hoti ṭhitaṃ āneñjappattaṃ vayañcassānupassati.
an6.55:17.2.eng: Their mind is quite untainted. It is steady, imperturbable, observing disappearance.

an6.55:17.7.pli: manoviññeyyā dhammā manassa āpāthaṃ āgacchanti, nevassa cittaṃ pariyādiyanti.
an6.55:17.7.eng: and ideas come into the range of the mind they don’t overcome the mind.

an6.55:17.8.pli: Amissīkatamevassa cittaṃ hoti ṭhitaṃ āneñjappattaṃ vayañcassānupassati.
an6.55:17.8.eng: Their mind is quite untainted. It is steady, imperturbable, observing disappearance.

an6.55:17.9.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, selo pabbato acchiddo asusiro ekagghano.
an6.55:17.9.eng: Suppose there was a mountain that was one solid mass of rock, without cracks or holes.

an6.55:17.10.pli: Atha puratthimāya cepi disāya āgaccheyya bhusā vātavuṭṭhi neva naṃ saṅkampeyya na sampakampeyya na sampavedheyya, atha pacchimāya cepi disāya āgaccheyya bhusā vātavuṭṭhi …
an6.55:17.10.eng: Even if violent storms were to blow up out of the east, the west, the north, and the south,

an6.55:17.11.pli: atha uttarāya cepi disāya āgaccheyya bhusā vātavuṭṭhi …

an6.55:17.12.pli: atha dakkhiṇāya cepi disāya āgaccheyya bhusā vātavuṭṭhi neva naṃ saṅkampeyya na sampakampeyya na sampavedheyya;
an6.55:17.12.eng: they couldn’t make it shake or rock or tremble.

an6.55:17.13.pli: evamevaṃ kho, bhante, evaṃ sammāvimuttacittassa bhikkhuno bhusā cepi cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā cakkhussa āpāthaṃ āgacchanti, nevassa cittaṃ pariyādiyanti.
an6.55:17.13.eng: In the same way, when a mendicant’s mind is rightly freed like this, even if compelling sights come into the range of vision they don’t overcome their mind. …

an6.55:17.14.pli: Amissīkatamevassa cittaṃ hoti, ṭhitaṃ āneñjappattaṃ vayañcassānupassati.

an6.55:17.19.pli: manoviññeyyā dhammā manassa āpāthaṃ āgacchanti, nevassa cittaṃ pariyādiyanti.

an6.55:17.20.pli: Amissīkatamevassa cittaṃ hoti ṭhitaṃ āneñjappattaṃ vayañcassānupassatīti.
an6.55:17.20.eng: Their mind is quite untainted. It is steady, imperturbable, observing disappearance.

an6.55:19.1.eng: when you’re dedicated to the ending of craving

an6.55:19.3.eng: and you’ve seen the arising of the senses,

an6.55:22.1.eng: and ideas, whether liked or disliked,

an6.55:22.3.eng: Their mind is steady and free

an6.56:1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā phagguno ābādhiko hoti dukkhito bāḷhagilāno.
an6.56:1.1.eng: Now at that time Venerable Phagguna was sick, suffering, gravely ill.

an6.56:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an6.56:1.2.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an6.56:1.4.pli: Sādhu, bhante, bhagavā yenāyasmā phagguno tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṃ upādāyā”ti.
an6.56:1.4.eng: Sir, please go to Venerable Phagguna out of sympathy.”

an6.56:1.6.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yenāyasmā phagguno tenupasaṅkami.
an6.56:1.6.eng: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to Venerable Phagguna.

an6.56:1.7.pli: Addasā kho āyasmā phagguno bhagavantaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.
an6.56:1.7.eng: Venerable Phagguna saw the Buddha coming off in the distance

an6.56:1.9.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ phaggunaṃ etadavoca:

an6.56:1.10.eng: “It’s all right, Phagguna, don’t get up.

an6.56:1.11.pli: Santimāni āsanāni parehi paññattāni, tatthāhaṃ nisīdissāmī”ti.
an6.56:1.11.eng: There are some seats spread out by others, I will sit there.”

an6.56:1.12.eng: He sat on the seat spread out

an6.56:1.13.pli: Nisajja kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ phaggunaṃ etadavoca:

an6.56:2.1.pli: “Kacci te, phagguna, khamanīyaṃ kacci yāpanīyaṃ? Kacci te dukkhā vedanā paṭikkamanti, no abhikkamanti; paṭikkamosānaṃ paññāyati, no abhikkamo”ti?
an6.56:2.1.eng: “I hope you’re keeping well, Phagguna; I hope you’re all right. And I hope the pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.”

an6.56:2.2.pli: “Na me, bhante, khamanīyaṃ na yāpanīyaṃ. Bāḷhā me dukkhā vedanā abhikkamanti, no paṭikkamanti; abhikkamosānaṃ paññāyati, no paṭikkamo.
an6.56:2.2.eng: “Sir, I’m not keeping well, I’m not getting by. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing is evident, not its fading.

an6.56:3.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, balavā puriso tiṇhena sikharena muddhani abhimattheyya; evamevaṃ kho me, bhante, adhimattā vātā muddhani ūhananti.
an6.56:3.1.eng: The winds piercing my head are so severe, it feels like a strong man drilling into my head with a sharp point.

an6.56:3.2.pli: Na me, bhante, khamanīyaṃ na yāpanīyaṃ. Bāḷhā me dukkhā vedanā abhikkamanti, no paṭikkamanti; abhikkamosānaṃ paññāyati, no paṭikkamo.

an6.56:4.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, balavā puriso daḷhena varattakkhaṇḍena sīsaveṭhanaṃ dadeyya; evamevaṃ kho me, bhante, adhimattā sīse sīsavedanā.
an6.56:4.1.eng: The pain in my head is so severe, it feels like a strong man tightening a strong leather strap around my head.

an6.56:4.2.pli: Na me, bhante, khamanīyaṃ na yāpanīyaṃ. Bāḷhā me dukkhā vedanā abhikkamanti, no paṭikkamanti; abhikkamosānaṃ paññāyati, no paṭikkamo.

an6.56:5.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, dakkho goghātako vā goghātakantevāsī vā tiṇhena govikantanena kucchiṃ parikanteyya; evamevaṃ kho me, bhante, adhimattā vātā kucchiṃ parikantanti.
an6.56:5.1.eng: The winds slicing my belly are so severe, like a deft butcher or their apprentice were slicing open a cows’s belly with a sharp meat cleaver.

an6.56:5.2.pli: Na me, bhante, khamanīyaṃ na yāpanīyaṃ. Bāḷhā me dukkhā vedanā abhikkamanti, no paṭikkamanti; abhikkamosānaṃ paññāyati, no paṭikkamo.

an6.56:6.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, dve balavanto purisā dubbalataraṃ purisaṃ nānābāhāsu gahetvā aṅgārakāsuyā santāpeyyuṃ samparitāpeyyuṃ; evamevaṃ kho me, bhante, adhimatto kāyasmiṃ ḍāho.
an6.56:6.1.eng: The burning in my body is so severe, it feels like two strong men grabbing a weaker man by the arms to burn and scorch him on a pit of glowing coals.

an6.56:6.2.pli: Na me, bhante, khamanīyaṃ na yāpanīyaṃ. Bāḷhā me dukkhā vedanā abhikkamanti, no paṭikkamanti; abhikkamosānaṃ paññāyati, no paṭikkamo”ti.
an6.56:6.2.eng: I’m not keeping well, I’m not getting by. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing is evident, not its fading.”

an6.56:6.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ phaggunaṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandassetvā samādapetvā samuttejetvā sampahaṃsetvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmi.
an6.56:6.3.eng: Then the Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired Venerable Phagguna with a Dhamma talk, after which he got up from his seat and left.

an6.56:7.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā phagguno acirapakkantassa bhagavato kālamakāsi.
an6.56:7.1.eng: Not long after the Buddha left, Venerable Phagguna passed away.

an6.56:7.2.pli: Tamhi cassa samaye maraṇakāle indriyāni vippasīdiṃsu.
an6.56:7.2.eng: At the time of his death, his faculties were bright and clear.

an6.56:7.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an6.56:7.3.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

an6.56:7.4.eng: “Sir, soon after the Buddha left, Venerable Phagguna died.

an6.56:7.5.pli: Tamhi cassa samaye maraṇakāle indriyāni vippasīdiṃsū”ti.
an6.56:7.5.eng: At the time of his death, his faculties were bright and clear.”

an6.56:8.1.pli: “Kiṃ hānanda, phaggunassa bhikkhuno indriyāni na vippasīdissanti.
an6.56:8.1.eng: “And why shouldn’t his faculties be bright and clear?

an6.56:8.2.pli: Phaggunassa, ānanda, bhikkhuno pañcahi orambhāgiyehi saṃyojanehi cittaṃ avimuttaṃ ahosi.
an6.56:8.2.eng: The mendicant Phagguna’s mind was not freed from the five lower fetters.

an6.56:8.3.pli: Tassa taṃ dhammadesanaṃ sutvā pañcahi orambhāgiyehi saṃyojanehi cittaṃ vimuttaṃ.
an6.56:8.3.eng: But when he heard that teaching his mind was freed from them.

an6.56:9.1.pli: Chayime, ānanda, ānisaṃsā kālena dhammassavane kālena atthupaparikkhāya.
an6.56:9.1.eng: Ānanda, there are these six benefits to hearing the teaching at the right time and examining the meaning at the right time.

an6.56:9.3.pli: Idhānanda, bhikkhuno pañcahi orambhāgiyehi saṃyojanehi cittaṃ avimuttaṃ hoti.
an6.56:9.3.eng: Firstly, take the case of a mendicant whose mind is not freed from the five lower fetters.

an6.56:9.4.pli: So tamhi samaye maraṇakāle labhati tathāgataṃ dassanāya.
an6.56:9.4.eng: At the time of death they get to see the Realized One.

an6.56:9.5.pli: Tassa tathāgato dhammaṃ deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāseti.
an6.56:9.5.eng: The Realized One proclaims a teaching to them that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

an6.56:9.6.pli: Tassa taṃ dhammadesanaṃ sutvā pañcahi orambhāgiyehi saṃyojanehi cittaṃ vimuccati.
an6.56:9.6.eng: When they hear that teaching their mind is freed from the five lower fetters.

an6.56:9.7.pli: Ayaṃ, ānanda, paṭhamo ānisaṃso kālena dhammassavane.
an6.56:9.7.eng: This is the first benefit of listening to the teaching.

an6.56:10.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, ānanda, bhikkhuno pañcahi orambhāgiyehi saṃyojanehi cittaṃ avimuttaṃ hoti.
an6.56:10.1.eng: Next, take the case of another mendicant whose mind is not freed from the five lower fetters.

an6.56:10.2.pli: So tamhi samaye maraṇakāle na heva kho labhati tathāgataṃ dassanāya, api ca kho tathāgatasāvakaṃ labhati dassanāya.
an6.56:10.2.eng: At the time of death they don’t get to see the Realized One, but they get to see a Realized One’s disciple.

an6.56:10.3.pli: Tassa tathāgatasāvako dhammaṃ deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāseti.
an6.56:10.3.eng: The Realized One’s disciple teaches them Dhamma …

an6.56:10.4.pli: Tassa taṃ dhammadesanaṃ sutvā pañcahi orambhāgiyehi saṃyojanehi cittaṃ vimuccati.
an6.56:10.4.eng: When they hear that teaching their mind is freed from the five lower fetters.

an6.56:10.5.pli: Ayaṃ, ānanda, dutiyo ānisaṃso kālena dhammassavane.
an6.56:10.5.eng: This is the second benefit of listening to the teaching.

an6.56:11.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, ānanda, bhikkhuno pañcahi orambhāgiyehi saṃyojanehi cittaṃ avimuttaṃ hoti.
an6.56:11.1.eng: Next, take the case of another mendicant whose mind is not freed from the five lower fetters.

an6.56:11.2.pli: So tamhi samaye maraṇakāle na heva kho labhati tathāgataṃ dassanāya, napi tathāgatasāvakaṃ labhati dassanāya;
an6.56:11.2.eng: At the time of death they don’t get to see the Realized One, or to see a Realized One’s disciple.

an6.56:11.3.pli: api ca kho yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ cetasā anuvitakketi anuvicāreti manasānupekkhati.
an6.56:11.3.eng: But they think about and consider the teaching in their heart, examining it with the mind as they learned and memorized it.

an6.56:11.4.pli: Tassa yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ cetasā anuvitakkayato anuvicārayato manasānupekkhato pañcahi orambhāgiyehi saṃyojanehi cittaṃ vimuccati.
an6.56:11.4.eng: As they do so their mind is freed from the five lower fetters.

an6.56:11.5.pli: Ayaṃ, ānanda, tatiyo ānisaṃso kālena atthupaparikkhāya.
an6.56:11.5.eng: This is the third benefit of listening to the teaching.

an6.56:12.1.pli: Idhānanda, bhikkhuno pañcahi orambhāgiyehi saṃyojanehi cittaṃ vimuttaṃ hoti, anuttare ca kho upadhisaṅkhaye cittaṃ avimuttaṃ hoti.
an6.56:12.1.eng: Next, take the case of a mendicant whose mind is freed from the five lower fetters, but not with the supreme ending of attachments.

an6.56:12.2.pli: So tamhi samaye maraṇakāle labhati tathāgataṃ dassanāya.
an6.56:12.2.eng: At the time of death they get to see the Realized One.

an6.56:12.3.pli: Tassa tathāgato dhammaṃ deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ …pe… brahmacariyaṃ pakāseti.
an6.56:12.3.eng: The Realized One teaches them Dhamma …

an6.56:12.4.pli: Tassa taṃ dhammadesanaṃ sutvā anuttare upadhisaṅkhaye cittaṃ vimuccati.
an6.56:12.4.eng: When they hear that teaching their mind is freed with the supreme ending of attachments.

an6.56:12.5.pli: Ayaṃ, ānanda, catuttho ānisaṃso kālena dhammassavane.
an6.56:12.5.eng: This is the fourth benefit of listening to the teaching.

an6.56:13.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, ānanda, bhikkhuno pañcahi orambhāgiyehi saṃyojanehi cittaṃ vimuttaṃ hoti, anuttare ca kho upadhisaṅkhaye cittaṃ avimuttaṃ hoti.
an6.56:13.1.eng: Next, take the case of another mendicant whose mind is freed from the five lower fetters, but not with the supreme ending of attachments.

an6.56:13.2.pli: So tamhi samaye maraṇakāle na heva kho labhati tathāgataṃ dassanāya, api ca kho tathāgatasāvakaṃ labhati dassanāya.
an6.56:13.2.eng: At the time of death they don’t get to see the Realized One, but they get to see a Realized One’s disciple.

an6.56:13.3.pli: Tassa tathāgatasāvako dhammaṃ deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ …pe… parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāseti.
an6.56:13.3.eng: The Realized One’s disciple teaches them Dhamma …

an6.56:13.4.pli: Tassa taṃ dhammadesanaṃ sutvā anuttare upadhisaṅkhaye cittaṃ vimuccati.
an6.56:13.4.eng: When they hear that teaching their mind is freed with the supreme ending of attachments.

an6.56:13.5.pli: Ayaṃ, ānanda, pañcamo ānisaṃso kālena dhammassavane.
an6.56:13.5.eng: This is the fifth benefit of listening to the teaching.

an6.56:14.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, ānanda, bhikkhuno pañcahi orambhāgiyehi saṃyojanehi cittaṃ vimuttaṃ hoti, anuttare ca kho upadhisaṅkhaye cittaṃ avimuttaṃ hoti.
an6.56:14.1.eng: Next, take the case of another mendicant whose mind is freed from the five lower fetters, but not with the supreme ending of attachments.

an6.56:14.2.pli: So tamhi samaye maraṇakāle na heva kho labhati tathāgataṃ dassanāya, napi tathāgatasāvakaṃ labhati dassanāya;
an6.56:14.2.eng: At the time of death they don’t get to see the Realized One, or to see a Realized One’s disciple.

an6.56:14.3.pli: api ca kho yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ cetasā anuvitakketi anuvicāreti manasānupekkhati.
an6.56:14.3.eng: But they think about and consider the teaching in their heart, examining it with the mind as they learned and memorized it.

an6.56:14.4.pli: Tassa yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ cetasā anuvitakkayato anuvicārayato manasānupekkhato anuttare upadhisaṅkhaye cittaṃ vimuccati.
an6.56:14.4.eng: As they do so their mind is freed with the supreme ending of attachments.

an6.56:14.5.pli: Ayaṃ, ānanda, chaṭṭho ānisaṃso kālena atthupaparikkhāya.
an6.56:14.5.eng: This is the sixth benefit of listening to the teaching.

an6.56:15.1.pli: Ime kho, ānanda, cha ānisaṃsā kālena dhammassavane kālena atthupaparikkhāyā”ti.
an6.56:15.1.eng: These are the six benefits to hearing the teaching at the right time and examining the meaning at the right time.”
